Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the step-parent should provide guidance
Situation2: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Story: I glance at the clock above my register, feeling the pressure of the lunch rush as the line snakes past the bakery display. My smile is fixed, my voice cheerful, as I greet each customer and scan their items. I know the store expects me to be quick and friendly, to make every shopper feel welcome, even when I’m tired or distracted. But my phone buzzes in my apron pocket—my partner’s message: “Can you talk to Jamie? He was rude to his teacher again.” I picture Jamie at home, slouched at the kitchen table, waiting for me to come home and explain why respect matters, why kindness is important. I’m supposed to be the adult who guides him, who helps him grow into a good person, even though I’m still learning how to be his parent. The customers keep coming, their faces blurring together, each expecting a smile, a thank you, a little warmth. My mind is split—half here, half at home—torn between the child who needs my guidance and the job that demands my attention. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which part of me should come first.
